results.statement:
21. Midline catheter tip position and catheter-related complications in antimicrobial therapy: A multi-center randomized controlled trial
(Zhao L et al. Int J Nurs Stud. 2023)
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 21

results.statement: Study protocol. Inclusion criteria: (1) IV infusion expected ≥1 week before catheterization, (2) age ≥18 years, (3) antimicrobial therapy during hospitalization with pH 5–9 and osmolarity <900 mOsm/L, (4) conscious, communicative patients, and (5) catheter-to-vessel ratio <45%.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 1

results.statement: Study protocol. Exclusion criteria: (1) history of radiotherapy, thrombosis, or trauma at the catheter site, and (2) planned discharge with the catheter during the study.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Study protocol. Evaluation indicators and judgment criteria were incidence of catheter-related complications and indwelling catheter duration.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 10

results.statement: Study protocol. Detailed history-taking, including medical history, and clinical exams were provided to all participants were, and written informed consent was obtained.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Study protocol. The catheter tip was placed in the subclavian vein in Group 1
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 7

results.statement: Study protocol. the axillary vein of the chest wall in Group 2
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 8

results.statement: Study protocol. and distal to the axillary vein in the control group.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 9

results.statement: Study findings. The total incidence of complications was 31.33% in the control group (distal axillary vein), 11.93% in group 1 (subclavian), and 16.85% in group 2 (axillary chest wall).
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 1

results.statement: Study findings. Longest dwell time recorded was of 131 days.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Study findings. First-attempt insertion success exceeded 90% across all groups, with ultrasound guidance contributing to catheter stability and reduced thrombosis rates.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Key points. MC tips placed in the subclavian or axillary vein of the chest wall had the lowest complication rates.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement: Study conclusions. Placing midline catheter tips in the subclavian or axillary vein significantly reduces catheter-related complications during antimicrobial therapy.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 8

22. Comparing incidence of thrombosis in PICC and midlines and evaluating the role of anticoagulation, site of insertion, and risk factors
(Zohourian H et al. J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019)
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 22

results.statement: Study protocol. Inclusion criteria: Adult patients who underwent either a PICC or midline catheter placement between January 1 and December 31, 2016.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement: Study protocol. Exclusion criteria: (1) age under 18, (2) presence of thrombosis in the arm opposite to catheter insertion, (3) prior thrombosis in the same arm as the catheter, (4) catheter placement prior to hospital admission, (5) presence of an isolated superficial thrombus, or (6) incomplete data.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Study protocol. Clinical information was extracted from electronic medical records by trained abstractors.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 4

results.statement: Study protocol. The means or frequencies of potential catheter-related thrombosis (CT) risk factors were compared between cases and controls.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement: Patient population. 1,683 catheters evaluated, including 123 midlines and 1560 PICCs, with 92 CT cases and 1,591 controls.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Study protocol. Data collected included details on deep vein thrombosis (DVT), the number of insertion attempts, insertion site (vein and arm), type of catheter (PICC or midline), lumen count, gauge, and catheter length.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement: A total of 123 midline catheters were analyzed, with 6 cases of catheter-related thrombosis (CT) (4.88% СТ rate). Among 1,560 PICCs, 86 cases of CT were reported (5.83% CT rate). The difference in CT rates between midlines and PICCs was not statistically significant.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 1

results.statement: Study findings. The insertion site, whether basilic, brachial, or cephalic vein, did not significantly affect the risk of thrombosis.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement: Study findings. Several risk factors were found to be significantly associated with catheter-related thrombosis, including the use of triple-lumen catheters, catheter placement in the ICU, presence of line infections, a history of thrombophilia, and the presence of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter or pacemaker.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Study findings. Prophylactic anticoagulation showed reduced CT trend but was not statistically significant.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 4

results.statement: Identified risk factors are associated with increased rate of thrombosis. A clinical prediction score can objectively identify high risk patients. There was no statistical difference in thrombosis event between vein insertion sites or use of prophylactic anticoagulation.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Study conclusions. Midline catheters demonstrated a slightly lower, though not statistically significant, incidence of thrombosis compared to PICCs, with several patient and device factors influencing CT risk.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement:
23. Midline venous catheters as an alternative to central line catheter placement: a product evaluation
(Car A et al. Br J Nurs. 2021)
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 23

results.statement: Study protocol. Patients ranged in age from 5 months to 23 years, with an average age of 10.7 years. Weights ranged from 3.8 kg to 100 kg, with an average weight of 43.7 kg.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement: Study protocol. In infants, the Powerwand ® was typically inserted in the lower leg or upper arm, while in toddlers and older children, it was placed in the forearm or upper arm.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Patient population. 44 catheters were placed in 34 pediatric patients.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 4

results.statement: Study findings. Patients were spared an average of 12 vascular access attempts, during their hospitalization, when Powerwand was used.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 1

results.statement: Study findings. The average dwell time was 8.1 days, with a maximum duration of 29 days in most cases. The average number of insertion attempts was 1, indicating a high rate of first-attempt success.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 2

results.statement: No bloodstream infections were reported. The overall complication rate was 16%, primarily due to minor extravasation. The complication rate per 1,000 catheter days was 1.00, compared to 3.26 for peripheral venous catheters (PVCs).
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: On average, the use of these catheters prevented average 6.1 PVC reinsertions and 6.3 blood draw sticks per patient. In terms of cost, each Powerwand ® catheter cost $170.25, compared to $32.55 per PVC. This resulted in an overall cost saving of $2,892.45 due to the reduction in PVC use.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 5

results.statement: Key points. Midline catheters are becoming more prevalent in both inpatient and outpatient settings.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 6

results.statement: Study conclusions. The Powerwand® midline catheter offers a safe, durable, and cost-effective alternative to CVCs and PVCs, reducing complications and improving vascular access outcomes across patient populations.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 8

results.statement: Key points. The Powerwand ® provides additional benefits from other midline catheters available related to the product composition and insertion technique
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 7

results.statement: Study findings. Midlines are appropriate for medium-term therapy (typically up to 4 weeks).

results.statement: Study findings. Midlines do not reach central veins, reducing risk of pneumothorax, cardiac arrhythmias, and central venous stenosis.

results.statement: Study findings. Lower risk of bloodstream infections than PICCs or CVCs.

results.statement: Study findings. Vancomycin and other medications previously considered vesicants are increasingly safe via midline.

results.statement: Study objective. To recommend safe and effective vascular access strategies for COVID-19 patients.
results.matched_evidence: No matching reference PDF was found for the extraction: 3

results.statement: Study findings. Midline catheters and mini-midlines are recommended for non-ICU COVID-19 patients over short peripheral cannulas.

results.statement: Study findings. Midlines reduce the number of insertions needed, leading to resource savings & lower exposure risks.

results.statement: Study findings. Midlines allow for high-flow infusion, easy blood sampling, and over-the-wire PICC upgrade if needed.
